questions.question_text: the following are all valid selectors except...
questions.explanation: We’ll talk through this one together.

questions.question_text: what is the difference between a class and an ID?

answers.answer_text: an ID can be assigned to multiple elements, a class to just one
IDs can only be assigned to specific HTML tags, and classes have no such restrictions
a class can be assigned to multiple elements, an ID to just one

questions.question_text: which of the following statements is false?

answers.answer_text: an element can be assigned both a class and an ID
an element can be assigned multiple classes
an element can be assigned multiple IDs

questions.explanation: It’s true: an element can have one or more classes assigned to it <strong>and</strong> have an ID assigned to it, too. (This is similar to the previous question but not quite.)

questions.question_text: you can include css styles in a webpage through all of the following methods except...

answers.answer_text: through a style attribute attached to an HTML element
through an external file via a <link> tag in the document’s <head>
through a <style> tag in the document’s <head>
through a <meta> tag in the document’s <head>

questions.explanation: All of these methods are legit except the one that ain’t. Learn more about including styles on your webpage on pages 235–236 of HTML & CSS.

questions.question_text: a descendent selector is present in which selector below?
questions.explanation: Learn more about the descendent selector here or on page 238 of HTML & CSS. Advanced selectors like the descendent selector allow you to reduce the amount of HTML on your webpages and reduce or eliminate the need to assign classes and IDs to elements.

questions.question_text: the cascade obeys the following rules except...

answers.answer_text: when two selectors are the same, the last rule wins
a more specific selector overrides a less specific selector
when two selectors are the same, an identical property's value can be manually overridden by suffixing it with “!important”
a less specific selector inherits the properties of a more specific selector

questions.explanation: Oops! I gave away the answer to question 1. And the correct answer here is just gibberish: selectors don't inherit properties, elements do. Learn more about the cascade on page 239 of HTML & CSS.

questions.question_text: of the following CSS properties below, which one is inherited from a parent element?
questions.explanation: If any of the properties except font-family were inherited, webpages would quickly become unusable. Learn more about inheritance on page 240 of HTML & CSS.

questions.question_text: true or false: caniuse.com is an excellent website to consult when you need to know whether a CSS property is supported by a specific version of a specific web browser.
questions.explanation: Uh, it’s true: caniuse.com is an excellent website to consult when you need to know whether a CSS property is supported by a specific version of a specific web browser. If you’re done with the quiz, check it out right now!
